name: 520 / 1040 STf / STfm
keyboard: Full stroke keyboard with numeric keypad, editing keypad and 10 function keys
rom: 32 KB with TOS on disk / 192 KB with TOS on ROM
graphics: 16 colors among 512 (320 x 200) / 4 colors among 512 (640 x 200)  / monochrome (640 x 400) this last mode needs a special monitor.
ports: Cartridge, Midi (in, out), Centronics, RS232c, Hard Disk, Floppy disk, RGB, Joystick, mouse
description:
The Atari 520 and 1040 STf were the direct successors of the Atari 260 ST and Atari 520 ST. In fact, they had the same technical characteristics except from built-in floppy drive (hence the f of STf).

The 3.5" floppy disk drive has been integrated with the power supply into the computer. The early first versions of the Atari 520 STf had a RAM based Operating System (they have a 32 KB ROM), this ROM will be quiclky replaced by a 192 KB ROM which holds all the operating system (called TOS 1.0).

An enhanced version of the Atari 520 STf was launched a few months later : the Atari 1040 STf to replace the Atari 520+ : It also had the same characteristics as the 520 STf except its memory (1 MB instead of the 512 KB) and the floppy disk drive : it used 3.5" double side disks (720 KB).
Not long after the launch of the 1040 STf, the 520 STf would be "unofficially" equipped with 720 KB floppy disk drives.
There was also a STfM model with a built-in floppy (the f) and an RF Modulator (the M).

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> SAME MODELS</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 520STF and 1040STF were same machines, apart from RAM size and floppy disk drive capacity.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT & RIGHT SIDES</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</b></font> Midi In and Out DIN sockets<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</b></font> ROM cartridges connector.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TWO 520 STF VERSIONS</strong></font><br><blockquote>The top one has 360 KB floppy disk, the bottom one has a 720 KB version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br><br> • Serial port dedicated to an external modem<br> • Parallel printer connector<br> • External hard disk drive interface<br> • External floppy disk drive interface (15-pin DIN socket)<br> • Monochrome or RGB monitor DIN socket<br> • Power switch and plug<br> • Reset switch (the grey plastic button is missing)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Like almost all Atari machines, the mainboard, power supply unit and floppy drive are surrounded with a metallic protection against magnetic fields.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 520 STF MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> 512 KB RAM chips (16x41256). Provision is made to upgrade the RAM size to 1 MB<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> TOS ROM's (2x32K)<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> MMU custom chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> 68000 CPU, here a Hitachi version<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> The Shifter custom video chip is protected by a metallic cover<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Glue custom chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Multi-Function Peripheral (MFP) chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> 2x6850 ACIA chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> Yamaha sound chipset<br> <b><font color="blue">(10)</font></b> Floppy disk controller chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(11)</font></b> DMA controller chip <br><br>For more information about each custom chip, see the 'Motherboard' picture of the Atari <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/museum/photos.asp?t=1&c=20&st=1" target="_blank">520ST</a> page. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1040 MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>All the RAM area is populated with 41256 chips.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAINBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>This version doesn't hold the TOS in ROM.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ATARI 2080 #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Just before launching the Mega-ST series, Atari sold little quantities of this unofficial 2MB RAM version called 2080STf. A 4160STf was also planned but never left the Commodore research department.   <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Sveto</b></p></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In U.K., at 1986 Christmas period, the 1040 STF was sold £799 + VAT for the 12" monochrome version, and £999 + VAT for the 14" colour version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> As the American magazine 'Byte' commented, "for some time to come the 1040STF will be the clear leader in price/performance." </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At the fingertip of the mouse..." <br><br> "... 16/32 bits technology"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1989</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special 520-STFM bundle advert.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There's no catch. We're giving you the Atari 520 STFM and £500 worth of great software titles for just £399.99.<br> The twenty-three super titles include some of the greatest games and three excellent programs which introduce you to the BASIC programming language, computer-created music and the more popular computer applications such as word processing and spreadsheets...</font></blockquote>

item.description: 170Mb Quantum hard-drive||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> 170MB QUANTUM HARD-DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This unit has an ICD Host Adapter.</blockquote>
Atari Megafile 30||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ATARI MEGAFILE 30</strong></font><br><blockquote>This hard-drive has a 30Mb capacity.</blockquote>

Inside the Megafile 30||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE THE MEGAFILE 30</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Seagate MFM 30 MB hard-disk Type ST-238<br> <b>(2)</b> Power supply<br> <b>(3)</b> Logical board<br> <b>(4)</b> Power and disk access LED's<br></blockquote>

Atari universal modem||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ATARI UNIVERSAL MODEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>The SX212 modem was one of the rare Atari peripherals that could be used with all the Atari computers range, from the 400/800 series up to the Falcon. It had both the Atari I/O ports for the 8-bit systems and a standard RS-232 connector for ST's<br><br> It was a 300/1200 baud modem compatible with the well-known Hayes 'AT' commands.<br> Cable and software was sold separately, depending of the computer used. </blockquote>

SML-804|||Laser printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SML-804</strong></font><br><strong>> Laser printer</strong><br><blockquote>The SLM-804 was actually a Kyocera F1000 printer but without neither on-board processor and memory nor buttons other than the on/off switch. It was first delivered with the Mega ST but could be connected on all of the ST series computers through a dedicated interface box.<br> The printer used the processing power and the RAM memory of the ST computer for printing at 8 pages per minute and 300 DPI. The paper tray held 250 sheets.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Francois Michaud</b> who donated us this printer.</p></blockquote>

SMLC-804|||Laser printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SMLC-804</strong></font><br><strong>> Laser printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>This interface allowed the SML-804 printer to be connected to any Atari ST holding at least 1 MB RAM.</blockquote>

emulator.name: Hatari
emulator.description: Hatari is an Atari ST emulator for Linux, BSD, BeOS, Mac OS X and other systems that are supported by the SDL library. More precisely, Hatari is an adaption of the WinSTon source code to the SDL library.
